From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>

On 19 September 2017 at 17:20, stefano.r.palmieri@... [neat]
<neat@yahoogroups.com> wrote:
>
>
>
> Colin, I believe that numpy's and scipy's code is vectorized for sigmoid and relu, not completely sure though.

Yeh I imagine they are, which I think broadly fits with what I'm
saying, i.e. if you optimize relu and sigmoid on a modern CPU then the
performance difference between the two will be significant (in the
everyday sense of the word, rather than the statistical sense).


> The final results are here: https://github.com/stefanopalmieri/k2graph-results/blob/master/sigmoid-retina-task-results.ods
>
> Trials are columns and rows are generations. The last entry in each row is the parameter settings, you can ignore it.
> 18 out of 40 trials succeeded (45%). That's lower than relu.

Thanks. How should I be interpreting the fitness scores? I take it
that 1,000 is the maximum/optimal score; what is the threshold between
success/failure?

Colin
